sentences.text: Both teams were making their Women's World Cup final debut. Spain had appeared in two previous Women's World Cups and advanced as far as the round of 16 in 2019 FIFA Women's World Cup|2019.

references.text: <ref name=":4">{{Cite news |last=Culpepper |first=Chuck |date=19 August 2023|title=Shiny and new, it's England and Spain for a World Cup final that fits |language=en-US |newspaper=The Washington Post |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/sports/2023/08/19/england-spain-womens-world-cup-final-preview/ |access-date=21 August 2023|issn=0190-8286}}</ref>

<ref name=":4" /> England had played in five previous Women's World Cups and achieved their best prior performance in 2015 FIFA Women's World Cup|2015, when they finished third.<ref>{{Cite news |last=Ewing |first=Lori |date=7 August 2023|title=England through to World Cup quarter-finals after beating Nigeria in shootout |language=en |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/sports/soccer/england-nigeria-round-16-clash-into-extra-time-2023-08-07/ |access-date=21 August 2023}}</ref>

sentences.text: This final was the third all-European final in Women's World Cup history after 1995 FIFA Women's World Cup final|1995 — when Norway women's national football team|Norway won their first title by beating Germany women's national football team|Germany in Stockholm — and 2003 FIFA Women's World Cup final|2003 — when Germany won their first title via a golden goal against Sweden women's national football team|Sweden in the United States to become the first country to have won both senior World Cups; at the time, their Germany national football team|men's team had won three world titles. The winner of the 2023 final would become the first European team to win the tournament since Germany in 2007 FIFA Women's World Cup|2007. The winners would also be the first new Women's World Cup champions since Japan women's national football team|Japan in 2011 FIFA Women's World Cup|2011.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/fifaplus/en/tournaments/womens/womensworldcup/australia-new-zealand2023/articles/spain-england-preview-womens-world-cup-2023-final|title=Spain v England: Live stream, where to watch, team news and more|date=19 August 2023|access-date=21 August 2023|publisher=FIFA}}</ref>

<ref name=EnglandFootball>{{cite web|url=https://www.englandfootball.com/england/womens-senior-team/fixtures-results/2023/england-women-v-spain-2023-fifa-world-cup-final-match-centre-report-sunday-20-august|title=Spain v England – FIFA Women's World Cup Final match centre|publisher=The Football Association|first=Nicholas|last=Veevers|date=19 August 2023|access-date=19 August 2023}}</ref>

sentences.text: Spain's Jorge Vilda managed in his fourth consecutive major championship and the second in the Women's World Cup. He became the first man to List of FIFA Women's World Cup winning managers|manage a Women's World Cup-winning side since Norio Sasaki with Japan in 2011 and the first European man since Even Pellerud in 1995 to win it.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |date=8 July 2023|title=Women's World Cup 2023 team guides part 11: Spain |language=en-GB |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2023/jul/09/womens-world-cup-2023-team-guides-part-11-spain |access-date=21 August 2023|issn=0261-3077}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=18 August 2023|title=Spain's World Cup run to final makes no sense. Or does it? |url=https://www.espn.in/football/story/_/id/38211948/spain-world-cup-run-final-surprise-amid-vilda-turmoil |access-date=21 August 2023|website=ESPN |language=en}}</ref>

<ref name="FORB">{{cite web |last1=Burhan |first1=Asif |title=Tony Gustavsson or Sarina Wiegman on Brink of Making World Cup History |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/asifburhan/2023/08/13/tony-gustavsson-or-sarina-wiegman-on-brink-of-making-world-cup-history/ |website=Forbes |access-date=22 August 2023|date=13 August 2023}}</ref>

sentences.text: England manager Sarina Wiegman was also at her fourth consecutive major championship, and fourth consecutive final after winning the 2017 Euros and finishing as runners-up in the 2019 Women's World Cup with her native Netherlands women's national football team|Netherlands in addition to winning the Women's Euro 2022 with England. She was the first person to lead different nations in multiple men's or women's World Cup finals and seeking to become the first manager to win either tournament with a foreign national team.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web|date=20 August 2023|title=Who is England coach Sarina Wiegman? Record and history of manager at FIFA Women's World Cup 2023|url=https://www.sportingnews.com/au/football/news/england-coach-sarina-wiegman-record-womens-world-cup-2023/y5gxhrdbvsgzeoyg5alh2kxr|access-date=21 August 2023|website=The Sporting News|language=en|first=Feargal|last=Brennan}}</ref>

<ref name="FORB" /> As she lost, she became the first manager to lose two successive World Cup finals.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Clarke|first1=George|last2=Harrington|first2=Anna|title=England's Wiegman feels pain of second WWC final loss|website=The Women's Game |url=https://thewomensgame.com/news/englands-wiegman-feels-pain-of-second-wwc-final-loss-599405 |access-date=22 August 2023|date=21 August 2023}}</ref>

sentences.text:
{{Further|Stadium Australia}}
The final was held at Stadium Australia (also known as Accor Stadium) in Sydney, New South Wales. The venue has a capacity of 75,784, and hosted four matches during the World Cup which included a semi-final. The stadium was confirmed to be the host of the final when the final stadiums for the World Cup was confirmed on the 31 March 2021.

references.text: <ref name=FIFAStadiums>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/fifaplus/en/tournaments/womens/womensworldcup/australia-new-zealand2023/articles/stadium-australia-womens-world-cup-2023|title=Stadium Australia|date=3 August 2023|access-date=19 August 2023|publisher=FIFA}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.fifa.com/womensworldcup/news/fifa-women-s-world-cup-2023tm-host-cities-and-stadiums-announced |title=FIFA Women's World Cup 2023 Host Cities and Stadiums announced |publisher=FIFA |date=31 March 2021 |access-date=14 October 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210331201128/https://www.fifa.com/womensworldcup/news/fifa-women-s-world-cup-2023tm-host-cities-and-stadiums-announced |archive-date=31 March 2021}}</ref>

sentences.text: Built for the 2000 Summer Olympics, it opened in March 1999. In addition to the opening and closing ceremonies and the track and field events, the stadium hosted the Football at the 2000 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament#Gold medal match|men's football gold medal match. The venue was also chosen as a venue for the men's 2015 AFC Asian Cup, where it hosted seven matches including the 2015 AFC Asian Cup final|final, which Australia won against South Korea to win the tournament for the first time. It was also the host of the 2005 shootout victory over Uruguay in the 2006 FIFA World Cup qualification (CONMEBOL–OFC play-off)|OFC–CONMEBOL playoff, which qualified the Socceroos for the 2006 FIFA World Cup|2006 World Cup, their first appearance since 1974.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |last=Sritharan |first=Joel |date=19 July 2023 |title=List of biggest, smallest Women's World Cup stadiums in Australia and New Zealand 2023 |url=https://www.sportingnews.com/au/football/news/list-biggest-smallest-womens-world-cup-stadiums-australia-and-new-zealand-2023/slj2dpng5supnkxltcx1bpjq |work=The Sporting News |accessdate=21 August 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://accorstadium.com.au/anz-stadium-the-major-venue-for-2015-afc-asian-cup/|title=ANZ Stadium The Major Venue For 2015 AFC Asian Cup|date=28 October 2013|access-date=19 August 2023|first=James|last=Conway|publisher=Accor Stadium}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last=Smith |first=Pete |date=15 November 2015 |title=Ten years since Australia v Uruguay: the story of the Socceroos' greatest moment |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/blog/2015/nov/16/ten-years-since-australia-v-uruguay-the-story-of-the-socceroos-greatest-moment |work=The Guardian |accessdate=20 August 2023}}</ref>

sentences.text: Spain first qualified to a major women's tournament in 1997, reaching the semi-finals of their first UEFA Women's Euro 1997|European Championship, and qualified for their first Women's World Cup in 2015. Their previous best performance in the Women's World Cup was elimination in the 2019 FIFA Women's World Cup knockout stage#Round of 16|round of 16 in 2019.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |date=14 August 2023 |title=Spain vs Sweden preview: Women's World Cup 2023 semi-final |url=https://www.aljazeera.com/sports/2023/8/14/spain-vs-sweden-preview-womens-world-cup-2023-semi-final |work=Al Jazeera Media Network|Al Jazeera |accessdate=20 August 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last=Brischetto |first=Patrick |date=20 August 2023 |title=Has Spain ever won the Women's World Cup? History, best finish in FIFA tournaments |url=https://www.sportingnews.com/us/soccer/news/has-spain-ever-won-womens-world-cup-history-best-finish-fifa/ikarcicyswvonyy8voicxyy9 |work=The Sporting News |accessdate=20 August 2023}}</ref>

sentences.text: Heading into the tournament, Spain was ranked sixth in the FIFA Women's World Ranking. They were drawn in 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup Group C|group C with Costa Rica women's national football team|Costa Rica, Zambia women's national football team|Zambia and 2011 champions Japan. Their opening match of the World Cup was against Costa Rica saw an own goal from Costa Rican player Valeria del Campo before goals from Aitana Bonmatí and Esther González in the space of four minutes secured a 3–0 victory. In the following match day, Spain booked a spot in the knockout stage with a 5–0 over Zambia with the opening goal being scored in the ninth minute by Teresa Abelleira before two goals from Alba Redondo and Jennifer Hermoso who was playing her 100th match got the victory. The final match day against Japan saw their Spanish be counterattacked with two goals from Japanese striker Hinata Miyazawa giving Japan a 4–0 win and placing Spain in second place for the group.

references.text: <ref name=FIFAWR>{{cite web |title=FIFA Women's Ranking – 9 June 2023 |url=https://www.fifa.com/fifa-world-ranking/women?dateId=ranking_20230609 |publisher=FIFA |access-date=18 June 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2022/oct/22/womens-world-cup-2023-the-complete-group-by-group-preview|title=Women's World Cup 2023: the complete group-by-group preview|first=Suzanne |last=Wrack|work=The Guardian|date=23 October 2022|access-date=17 August 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.eurosport.com/football/women-s-world-cup/2023/spain-v-costa-rica-world-cup-live_sto9706070/story.shtml|title=Spain 3–0 Costa Rica: La Roja start Women's World Cup campaign with win over Costa Rica, Aitana Bonmati in the goals|date=22 July 2023|access-date=17 August 2023|first=Oli |last=Gent|work=Eurosport}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2023/jul/26/spain-qualify-zambia-match-report-womens-world-cup|title=Spain cruise into World Cup last 16 with ruthless 5–0 victory over Zambia|work=The Guardian|first=Sid |last=Lowe|date=26 July 2023|access-date=17 August 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2023/jul/31/womens-world-cup-japan-spain-match-report|title=Hinata Miyazawa hits double as Japan slice through Spain to top Group C|work=The Guardian|date=31 July 2023|access-date=17 August 2023}}</ref>

sentences.text: In the round of 16, Spain took on 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup Group A|Group A winners Switzerland women's national football team|Switzerland. Bonmatí scored the opening goal in the 7th minute before an own goal from Laia Codina who back-passed to Cata Coll which gave the equaliser for Switzerland. The following 30 minutes saw Spain score three goals with Redondo, Bonmati and Codina all scoring to give Spain a 4–1 lead at half-time. After Switzerland almost a second goal from Meriame Terchoun, Spain sealed up the match with a fifth coming from Hermoso and securing a spot into the quarter-finals for the first time. Spain's quarter-final opponent was against the Netherlands who finished runner-up at the 2019 World Cup. The opening half saw the Spanish have a goal disallowed while the Dutch had a penalty being waved away. In the 81st minute, Mariona Caldentey scored from the penalty spot to give Spain the early lead after Stefanie van der Gragt had a hand touch the ball. Van der Gragt, who moved forward, got the equaliser nine minutes later with an assist from Victoria Pelova, putting the game into extra time. On the 111th minute, Salma Paralluelo scored the match winner and booked a semi-final spot. In the semis at Eden Park, Spain faced Sweden. They scored first through Paralluelo, before conceding an equaliser by Rebecka Blomqvist. Just a minute later, Olga Carmona scored a wonderful goal to send Spain to only its second senior World Cup final ever and the first since the men's 2010 FIFA World Cup final|2010 triumph over the Netherlands in Johannesburg.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2023/aug/05/switzerland-spain-womens-world-cup-last-16-report|title=Spain surge into World Cup quarters as Bonmatí leads rout of Switzerland|work=The Guardian|date=5 August 2023|access-date=19 August 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/fifaplus/en/tournaments/womens/womensworldcup/australia-new-zealand2023/articles/spain-v-netherlands-live-stream-where-to-watch-team-news-and-more|title=Spain v Netherlands: Live stream, where to watch, team news and more|date=10 August 2023|access-date=19 August 2023|publisher=FIFA}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2023/aug/11/spain-secure-spot-in-world-cup-semi-finals-with-extra-time-win-over-netherlands|title=Spain secure spot in World Cup semi-finals with extra-time win over Netherlands|first=Jonathan|last=Liew|date=11 August 2023|access-date=19 August 2023|work=The Guardian}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.skysports.com/football/spain-women-vs-holland-women/report/460884|title=Spain 2–1 Netherlands: Salma Paralluelo scores extra-time winner to send Jorge Vilda's side into Women's World Cup semi-finals|work=Sky Sports|date=11 August 2023|access-date=19 August 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2023/aug/15/womens-world-cup-semi-final-spain-sweden-match-report|title=Spain reach their first Women's World Cup final as late winner sinks Sweden |first=Sophie |last=Downey|date=15 August 2023|access-date=19 August 2023|work=The Guardian}}</ref>

sentences.text: England first qualified to a major women's tournament in 1984, finishing as runners-up in the 1984 European Competition for Women's Football|European Championship. They first qualified for the Women's World Cup in 1995 FIFA Women's World Cup|1995. Their previous best performance in the tournament was finishing 2015 FIFA Women's World Cup knockout stage#Third place play-off|third in 2015.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |last1=Sigsworth |first1=Tim |last2=Hallal |first2=Mariana |date=19 August 2023 |title='Battle of the Kenilworth bog': The England match pictures that show how far women's football has come |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/football/2023/08/19/world-cup-final-england-team-compared-lionesses-1984-2023/ |work=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=20 August 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last=Wrack |first=Suzanne |date=28 June 2019 |title=Rising swell of World Cup support is spurring England on, says Jade Moore |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2019/jun/28/only-winning-the-world-cup-will-satisfy-englands-players-admits-fran-kirby |work=The Guardian |accessdate=20 August 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last=Wright |first=Andrew |date=14 August 2023 |title=Women's World Cup 2023 semi-finals: Everything you need to know about the final four as England eye final |url=https://www.eurosport.com/football/women-s-world-cup/2023/women-s-world-cup-2023-semi-finals-everything-you-need-to-know-about-the-final-four_sto9743693/story.shtml |work=Eurosport |accessdate=20 August 2023}}</ref>

sentences.text: Heading into the tournament, the Lionesses had not only won their first major trophy at Women's Euro 2022 as hosts but also had gone on to defeat 2022 Copa América Femenina|Copa América Femenina winners Brazil women's national football team|Brazil on penalties at Wembley in the first Women's Finalissima. They had lost once with Sarina Wiegman as manager – a 2–0 friendly defeat to Australia in Brentford – and entered the Women's World Cup ranked fourth in the FIFA Women's World Ranking. In the first two games, England won 1–0 against both Haiti and Denmark; the winning goals were a penalty from Georgia Stanway and a goal from Lauren James. Needing a point to win the group, England defeated China 6–1 with James scoring two goals.

references.text: <ref name=FIFAWR/> They were drawn in 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup Group D|Group D with Haiti women's national football team|Haiti, Denmark women's national football team|Denmark, and 1999 runners-up China women's national football team|China.<ref>{{cite news |last1=Laverty |first1=Rich |title=Women's World Cup 2023 Group D Preview: England, China, Denmark, Haiti |url=https://theanalyst.com/eu/2023/07/womens-world-cup-2023-group-d-preview-england-china-denmark-haiti/ |access-date=18 August 2023 |work=The Analyst |date=17 July 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sanders |first1=Emma |title=Fifa Women's World Cup: England beat Haiti but given tough test in opener|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/66265569 |access-date=18 August 2023 |work=BBC Sport |date=22 July 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sanders |first1=Emma |title=England 1–0 Denmark: Lauren James stars as England beat Denmark|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/66290755|access-date=18 August 2023 |work=BBC Sport |date=28 July 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sanders |first1=Emma |title=China 1–6 England: Lauren James' stunning display powers England into last 16|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/66369572|access-date=18 August 2023 |work=BBC Sport |date=1 August 2023}}</ref>

sentences.text: In the round of 16, England faced 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup Group B|group B runners-up Nigeria women's national football team|Nigeria. During the match, the English were outplayed against the Nigerians. After initially getting a yellow card, James was then sent off after a Video assistant referee|VAR check for stepping on Michelle Alozie's back. After a goalless 120 minutes, the match went into Penalty shoot-out (association football)|penalties. After Stanway's shot went wide, the next four penalties were slotted in and with Nigeria missing two in return, England won the shoot-out 4–2. England next match was against Colombia women's national football team|Colombia who were playing in their first quarter-final at the World Cup. After Leicy Santos scored, England quickly equalised through Hemp before the first half ended. A 63rd-minute goal from Alessia Russo won the Lionesses a spot in the semis to face co-hosts Australia women's national soccer team|Australia. Ella Toone scored first, but Australia equalised through Sam Kerr. Hemp and Russo then scored to secure England a first Women's World Cup final and only its second senior World Cup final ever, the first since the men's 1966 FIFA World Cup final|1966 triumph over West Germany in London.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2023/aug/07/england-nigeria-womens-world-cup-match-report-lauren-james-red-card|title=England beat Nigeria on penalties to reach Women's World Cup quarter-finals|first=Suzanne|last=Wrack|date=7 August 2023|access-date=20 August 2023|work=The Guardian}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sanders |first1=Emma |title=England 0–0 Nigeria: Lionesses win penalty shootout to reach quarter-finals|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/66420237|access-date=19 August 2023 |work=BBC Sport |date=7 August 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/66439542|title=2023 Women's World Cup: Colombia 'dreaming big' as they book quarter-final against England|first=Emma|last=Smith|publisher=BBC|date=8 August 2023|access-date=20 August 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sanders |first1=Emma |title=England 2–1 Colombia: Lionesses book Women's World Cup semi-final with Australia |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/66470403|access-date=19 August 2023 |work=BBC Sport |date=12 August 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last1=Sanders |first1=Emma |title=Australia 1–3 England: Lionesses reach first Women's World Cup final |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/66499185|access-date=19 August 2023 |work=BBC Sport |date=16 August 2023}}</ref>

sentences.text: On 18 August 2023, FIFA named American official Tori Penso as the referee for the final. She became the first American referee to officiate a World Cup final after previously being the head referee for four matches of the World Cup including the semi-final between Australia and England, thus becoming the third referee ever and the first since Ivan Eklind in the 1934 FIFA World Cup|1934 men's World Cup to officiate a single World Cup semi-final and the final. Penso had been a FIFA International Referees List|FIFA international referee since 2021, refereed the 2021 NWSL Championship Game and had also become the first female referee in Major League Soccer history. Her assistants, Brooke Mayo and Kathryn Nesbitt, were also from the United States. They were joined by fourth official Yoshimi Yamashita of Japan.

references.text: <ref name=FIFARefereeAnnouncement>{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/fifaplus/en/tournaments/womens/womensworldcup/australia-new-zealand2023/articles/tori-penso-usa-named-final-referee|title=American Tori Penso named as FIFA Women's World Cup 2023™️ final referee|date=18 August 2023|access-date=19 August 2023|publisher=FIFA}}</ref>

<ref name="FORB2">{{cite web |last1=Burhan |first1=Asif |title=Tori Penso Becomes First United States Official To Referee A World Cup Final |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/asifburhan/2023/08/18/tori-penso-becomes-first-united-states-official-to-referee-a-world-cup-final/?sh=ee63f7151bf1 |website=Forbes |access-date=22 August 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web|url=https://resources.fifa.com/image/upload/2021-fifa-list-of-international-match-officials.pdf?cloudid=qy9ohgx0ugqacius6mc1|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210108124231/https://resources.fifa.com/image/upload/2021-fifa-list-of-international-match-officials.pdf?cloudid=qy9ohgx0ugqacius6mc1|title=2021 Refereeing International List|publisher=FIFA|archive-date=8 January 2021}}</ref>

<ref name="officials">{{cite news |url-access=registration|last=Woitalla |first=Mike |date=18 August 2023 |title=First U.S. ref for World Cup final: Tori Penso set for another milestone |url=https://www.socceramerica.com/publications/article/97251/first-us-ref-for-world-cup-final-tori-penso-set.html |work=Soccer America |accessdate=18 August 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last=Anderson |first=Jason |date=18 August 2023 |title=U.S. makes World Cup final after all as referee Penso gets England vs. Spain |url=https://prosoccerwire.usatoday.com/2023/08/17/world-cup-final-2023-referees-tori-penso-england-spain/ |work=USA Today |accessdate=18 August 2023}}</ref>

sentences.text: From their 2022 Women's Euro team that beat Spain in Brighton and Hove before winning that tournament, England could not call up captain Leah Williamson, player of the tournament and top scorer Beth Mead, or Fran Kirby due to knee injuries. The World Cup squad included some returning senior players and new young players instead. One of the young players called up after the 2022 Euro, Lauren James, was available to play in the final after a straight red card against Nigeria in the round of 16 resulted in her being suspended for the quarter-final and semi-final.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |last1=Braidwood |first1=Jamie |title=Lauren James 'will be ready' for World Cup final, says Chelsea manager Emma Hayes |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/lauren-james-england-womens-world-cup-final-b2395164.html |access-date=22 August 2023 |publisher=Independent |date=20 August 2023}}</ref>

sentences.text: Following the 2022 Euro, a group of 15 Spain players boycotted matches due to a dispute with the Royal Spanish Football Federation (RFEF) and manager Jorge Vilda. Several continued to boycott, with others excluded, and only 3 of the 15 were included in the World Cup squad. Two-time reigning Ballon d'Or Féminin winner Alexia Putellas was available for the tournament after recovering from an ACL injury. Oihane Hernández was available for the final after having accumulated two yellow cards and missing the semi-final.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |last=Tannenwald |first=Jonathan |date=19 August 2023 |title=Spain's brilliant rise to the World Cup final is clouded by players protesting the manager |url=https://www.inquirer.com/soccer/womens-world-cup-jorge-vilda-spain-protest-20230819.html |work=The Philadelphia Inquirer |accessdate=20 August 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |last=Lowe |first=Sid |date=30 September 2022|title=Jorge Vilda omits 15 players after Spain mutiny and refuses to step down |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2022/sep/30/jorge-vilda-leaves-out-15-internationals-and-refuses-to-step-down-as-spain-coach |access-date=18 August 2023|website=The Guardian}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last1=Mackey |first1=Ed |last2=Murray |first2=Noah |title=How Spain beat Sweden to set up Women's World Cup final against Australia or England |url=https://theathletic.com/live-blogs/spain-sweden-live-updates-womens-world-cup-2023-score-result/2uNc0OGDQiXW/gxEH2ThZg0n4/ |publisher=The Athletic |date=15 August 2023}}</ref>

sentences.text: Both of the teams were considered golden generations of the women's game in their countries, though each missing key players through the injuries and boycott.

references.text: <ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite news |last=Lewis |first=Samantha |date=2023-08-20 |title=Spain's World Cup win lays bare the progress and problems of women's football |work=ABC News |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2023-08-21/spain-women-world-cup-win-lays-bare-progress-problems/102753538}}</ref>

sentences.text: The combined tournament squads of England and Spain featured eleven players who, at the time the match was played, were signed to FC Barcelona Femení|Barcelona; ten (eight for Spain, two for England) played in the final.{{efn|Including returning transfer Ona Batlle}} The teammates had joked about meeting each other in the final, without truly expecting it. Ahead of the match, the awareness of each others' strengths and weaknesses was a point of discussion, as were the Barcelona players who had refused to play for Spain.<ref name=":0" />

references.text: <ref name=":0">{{Cite web |last=Collazos |first=David |date=2023-08-18 |title=La final del Mundial fememino, teñida de azulgrana |url=https://www.rtve.es/deportes/20230818/espana-inglaterra-jugadoras-barcelona-final-mundial-femenino-2023/2454168.shtml |access-date=2023-08-20 |website=RTVE.es |language=es}}</ref>

<ref name=":0"/> and Laia Codina, who was reported to be leaving the club in the days before the match.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/66541615|title=Laia Codina: Arsenal reach agreement for Barcelona defender|last=Sanders|first=Emma|date=18 August 2023|work=BBC Sport}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-08-19 |title=España llega a la final contra Inglaterra, apoyada en el éxito de Barcelona |url=https://www.vozdeamerica.com/a/espana-llega-a-la-final-contra-inglaterra-apoyada-en-el-exito-de-barcelona/7232124.html |access-date=2023-08-20 |website=Voz de América |language=es}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=17 August 2023 |title=Walsh and Bronze on blockbuster battle with Barça team-mates |url=https://www.fifa.com/fifaplus/en/tournaments/womens/womensworldcup/australia-new-zealand2023/articles/walsh-and-bronze-on-blockbuster-battle-with-barca-team-mates |website=FIFA}}</ref>

sentences.text: Both England (as part of the United Kingdom and Commonwealth realm|Commonwealth) and Spain are constitutional monarchies and are often represented at sporting events by members of their royal families. At the time, the president of the Royal Spanish Football Federation (RFEF) was Luis Rubiales, while William, Prince of Wales was president of The Football Association (The FA). Despite his position in football and as royalty, William said he would not travel to Australia (of which he is also royalty) to watch England in the final, citing the carbon footprint that would be generated.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |last=Klein-Nixon |first=Kylie |date=2023-08-19 |title='Large carbon footprint' behind Prince William not attending World Cup final |url=https://www.stuff.co.nz/sport/fifa-womens-world-cup-2023/132776452/large-carbon-footprint-behind-prince-william-not-attending-world-cup-final |access-date=2023-08-22 |website=Stuff |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: Rubiales had accompanied the Spain team throughout much of their time in New Zealand and Australia, with a report in Relevo suggesting he had imposed his presence around the players too closely, behaving more like a teammate than the president, and had normalised a level of paternalism and condescension. Spain's Queen Letizia of Spain|Queen Letizia travelled to Australia for the final with her younger daughter, the Infanta Sofía of Spain|Infanta Sofía. Included in the trip over her sister, Sofía is known to be a big fan of football as well as reportedly an aspiring defensive midfielder. The director of women's football for Barcelona, Xavi Puig, was also in attendance and allowed to accompany the Spain team, though stated to be supporting all the club's players.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-08-21 |title=No solo fue el beso: los gestos de Rubiales provocan una crisis y emborronan el título Mundial |url=https://www.relevo.com/futbol/mundial-femenino/campeonas-mundo-habla-desagrable-avergonzante-20230821100415-nt.html |access-date=2023-08-22 |website=Relevo |language=es}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-08-20 |title=Así saca partido la infanta Sofía a la final del Mundial de fútbol femenino en la que se desmarca de Leonor |url=https://www.lecturas.com/actualidad/casas-reales/asi-saca-partido-infanta-sofia-final-mundial-futbol-femenino-que-se-desmarca-leonor_143652 |access-date=2023-08-22 |website=Lecturas |language=es}}</ref>

sentences.text: The tournament's closing ceremony took place ahead of the final, featuring a Welcome to Country, and a performance from Australian singer Tones and I.

references.text: <ref>{{cite web |last1=Vinall |first1=Marnie |last2=Eder |first2=Billie |date=2023-08-20 |title=As it happened Women's World Cup: Spain are Women's World Cup champions with masterclass 1–0 defeat of England in final |url=https://www.theage.com.au/sport/soccer/women-s-world-cup-live-england-spain-face-off-in-stadium-australia-final-20230819-p5dxv8.html |access-date=2023-08-21 |website=The Age |language=en |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230822035321/https://www.theage.com.au/sport/soccer/women-s-world-cup-live-england-spain-face-off-in-stadium-australia-final-20230819-p5dxv8.html |archive-date=2023-08-22 |url-status=live}}</ref>

sentences.text: The match was described as a "pulsating game", difficult but with Spain creating more clear chances by the end.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite news |last=Pal |first=Alasdair |date=2023-08-20 |title=Spain defeat England in final of record-breaking Women's World Cup |work=Reuters |url=https://www.reuters.com/sports/soccer/england-spain-final-round-off-record-breaking-womens-world-cup-2023-08-20/}}</ref>

sentences.text: England started the match intensely, with Spain patient; The match "sprung into life" when Spain made their first substantial attack a minute later, with vice-captain Olga Carmona crossing a ball to Paralluelo, who could not connect fully but sent the ball into the path of Redondo: England goalkeeper Mary Earps made a quick-moving save to catch the shot from Redondo. Over the next few minutes, the match was played from end to end, with chances in for both teams.<ref name=":1" />

references.text: <ref name=":3" /> the first shot of the game came in the 5th minute from England forward Lauren Hemp shooting straight at Spain goalkeeper Cata Coll. Spain took advantage of the transition a minute later to launch a counterattack that saw centre forward Alba Redondo send in a loose cross. England then created chances with balls played through the lines to centre forward Alessia Russo; when Spain got the ball they held possession without taking advantage. After England holding midfielder Keira Walsh was fouled by Salma Paralluelo attempting to dispossess her, the England team created their best chance of the match, with Hemp having a clear shot on goal in the 16th minute but striking the crossbar.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web |date=2023-08-20 |title=England v Spain LIVE: Women's World Cup final result and reaction |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/england-spain-live-score-womens-world-cup-final-b2396015.html |access-date=2023-08-20 |website=The Independent}}</ref>

sentences.text: When England right wing-back Lucy Bronze attempted a dribble through the midfield, Spanish players dispossessed her and the ball was sent to Carmona, who took a tight-angled low shot past Earps and into the right corner of the net, scoring the only goal of the match in the 29th minute. England struggled after conceding the goal, allowing a confident Spain more chances,<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":1" /> though Spain's only shot on target in the rest of the half came when defender Irene Paredes was given space in the box to head the ball from a free kick in the 37th minute, which Earps kept out. England recovered close to the end of the first half, and a long ball to Hemp was crossed in for Ella Toone with an empty goal in the 42nd minute, though Toone failed to connect and the ball was recovered by Spain; the same sequence was used minutes later, with Spain sending players into the box to clear Hemp's cross. In the one minute of added time at the end of the first half, Paralluelo also hit the crossbar.<ref name=":1" />

references.text: <ref name=":1" /> Spanish media noted that although Spain's team featured more players from Barcelona than any other club, the goal did not come from possession play but from a quick counterattack, more like the play of Real Madrid Femenino|Real Madrid, which the Spain women's team had increasingly played like.<ref name=":2">{{Cite web |last=García |first=Pablo Macías |date=2023-08-20 |title=España vence a Inglaterra y se proclama campeona del Mundial de Australia y Nueva Zelanda |url=https://elpais.com/deportes/mundial-futbol-femenino/2023-08-20/espana-inglaterra-en-directo-final-del-mundial-de-australia-y-nueva-zelanda-en-vivo.html |access-date=2023-08-20 |website=El País |language=es}}</ref>

sentences.text: Returning from half time, England changed formation from the 3–5–2 that they had adopted in the group stage, returning to the 4–3–3 they had consistently used under Wiegman throughout her tenure. Wingers Lauren James and Chloe Kelly came on for left wing-back Rachel Daly and Russo. The change initially saw England improve defensively and create better opportunities, including the fullbacks continuing to play forward; Spain substituted centre forward Redondo for defensive player Oihane Hernández in the 60th minute, with Spain attacking midfielder Aitana Bonmatí trying to score from range in the 62nd minute. England's confidence waned and Spain's was bolstered when Walsh conceded a penalty for accidental handball in the box while defending a corner in the 65th minute.<ref name=":1" /> After a lengthy Video assistant referee|VAR review, Spain forward Jennifer Hermoso took the penalty in the 70th minute, with the shot saved by Earps. Spain defender Laia Codina was treated and eventually substituted with an injury in the 73rd minute, being replaced by captain Ivana Andrés. England briefly found form again after the substitution, with James able to send in a tight-angled shot narrowly saved by Coll, but were hampered by defender Alex Greenwood receiving a head injury from Paralluelo's high knee in the 78th minute. Greenwood managed to continue, with play resuming in the 82nd minute and England playing desperately.<ref name=":1" />

references.text: <ref name=":3">{{Cite news |title=Lionesses miss opportunity to cement legend status |language=en-GB |work=BBC Sport |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/66562418 |access-date=2023-08-20}}</ref>

sentences.text: In the 23rd minute of the match, a man Pitch invasion|ran onto the field wearing an anti-Vladimir Putin|Putin t-shirt, halting play briefly while England was waiting to take a free kick. The free kick was gathered by Spain, who counterattacked unsuccessfully.<ref name=":1" />

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-08-20 |title=Anti-Putin protest interrupts Women's World Cup final |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/protest-putin-pitch-invader-womens-world-cup-b2396199.html |access-date=2023-08-20 |website=The Independent}}</ref>

sentences.text: During a celebration when Spain scored, manager Vilda hugged a female assistant; initially having his hand on her shoulder, he appeared to move it down to her breast and hold this a moment before removing his hand. The moment was captured on camera and re-examined after the match and an incident of Rubiales kissing a player without consent.

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-08-22 |title=Spain boss Jorge Vilda appears to grab breast of female coach during World Cup final |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/jorge-vilda-grope-grab-womens-world-cup-spain-b2397138.html |access-date=2023-08-22 |website=The Independent |language=en}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |first1=Jill |last1=Martin |first2=Matias |last2=Grez |date=2023-08-22 |title=Spain's head coach Jorge Vilda appears to touch female staffer inappropriately during game celebration |url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/08/22/football/jorge-vilda-spt-intl/index.html |access-date=2023-08-22 |website=CNN |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: Near the end of the match, England player Bronze approached Vilda at the side of the pitch and remonstrated him. Coming after several fouls on England, and when Vilda and his staff were crowding the touchline, Bronze told Australian media that she "just told them to sit down".

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-08-21 |title=England star explodes over unseen act late in fiery final |url=https://7news.com.au/sport/fifa-womens-world-cup/england-star-lucy-bronze-fires-up-over-spains-infuriating-act-late-in-fifa-womens-world-cup-final-c-11654907 |access-date=2023-08-22 |website=7NEWS |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text:
'''Assistant referee (association football)|Assistant referees:'''<noinclude>
*90 minutes.
*30 minutes of Overtime (sports)#Association football|extra time if necessary.
*Penalty shoot-out (association football)|Penalty shoot-out if scores still level.
*Maximum of twelve named substitutes.
*Maximum of five substitutions, with a sixth allowed in extra time.{{refn|group=note|Each team was given only three opportunities to make substitutions, with a fourth opportunity in extra time, excluding substitutions made at half-time, before the start of extra time and at half-time in extra time.}}
|}

|style="width:60%;vertical-align:top"| '''Match rules'''{{cite web |url=https://digitalhub.fifa.com/m/7444397eecf3d01e/original/FWWC2023_Regulations_EN.pdf |title=Regulations: FIFA Women's World Cup Australia & New Zealand 2023 |publisher=FIFA |access-date=14 December 2022}}

sentences.text: Spain became the second country to have won both men's and women's World Cups and also the second country—after Brazil's male teams between 2003 and 2005—to simultaneously hold all three World Cups of the same gender (senior, under-20, and under-17).{{efn|Brazil won the 2002 FIFA World Cup, 2003 FIFA World Youth Championship, and 2003 FIFA U-17 World Championship. Spain won the 2023 FIFA Women's World Cup, 2022 FIFA U-20 Women's World Cup, and 2022 FIFA U-17 Women's World Cup.}} Salma Paralluelo became the first player of any gender to have won all three World Cups of the same gender. Spain's captain for the match and goalscorer Olga Carmona was named player of the match. After she scored, she lifted her shirt to reveal an undershirt with "Merchi" written on it, the name of her friend's mother who had recently died. In the press room after the match, she dedicated the victory to her.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |last1=Meenaghan |first1=Gary |title=When Iniesta and football's future stars discovered UAE's passion: The 2003 Fifa World Youth Championships |url=https://www.thenationalnews.com/sport/when-iniesta-and-football-s-future-stars-discovered-uae-s-passion-the-2003-fifa-world-youth-championships-1.15532 |access-date=29 August 2023 |work=The National (Abu Dhabi)|The National |date=29 July 2015 |quote=Brazil, in contrast, were delighted: the victory completed a remarkable treble for the South American nation, whose senior team had won the World Cup a year earlier in Japan and South Korea, and whose Under 17s had beat Cesc Fabregas's Spain in their own world championship final a few months later.}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web |date=20 August 2023 |title=How Spain became the holders of all three Women's World Cups|publisher=FIFA |url=https://www.fifa.com/fifaplus/en/tournaments/womens/womensworldcup/australia-new-zealand2023/articles/spain-womens-world-cup-2023-u17-u20-winners |access-date=21 August 2023 |website=FIFA.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230822034216/https://www.fifa.com/fifaplus/en/tournaments/womens/womensworldcup/australia-new-zealand2023/articles/spain-womens-world-cup-2023-u17-u20-winners |archive-date=22 August 2023|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite web |date=21 August 2023 |title=Paralluelo crosses finish line with third winners' medal|publisher=FIFA |url=https://www.fifa.com/fifaplus/en/tournaments/womens/womensworldcup/australia-new-zealand2023/articles/spain-salma-paralluelo-womens-world-cup-u-17-u-20-champion-2023 |access-date=8 September 2023 |website=FIFA.com |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20230908180812/https://www.fifa.com/fifaplus/en/tournaments/womens/womensworldcup/australia-new-zealand2023/articles/spain-salma-paralluelo-womens-world-cup-u-17-u-20-champion-2023 |archive-date=8 September 2023|url-status=live}}</ref>

<ref name=":2" /> She was told shortly afterward that her own father had died before the match.<ref>{{Cite news |date=2023-08-20 |title=Spain World Cup hero Olga Carmona learns of father's death after final victory |language=en-AU |work=ABC News |url=https://www.abc.net.au/news/2023-08-21/spain-world-cup-final-hero-olga-carmona-learns-of-fathers-death/102753812 |access-date=2023-08-21}}</ref>

sentences.text: The Spain team boarded an overnight flight and returned to Madrid for a public celebration on the evening of 21 August, held at Madrid Río park with several thousand in attendance. The team's victory dominated the front pages of newspapers on 21 August, with emphatic headlines.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |last=Azzoni |first=Tales |date=21 August 2023 |title=Spain celebrates Women's World Cup at home with Carmona mourning but involved |url=https://www.sandiegouniontribune.com/sports/national/story/2023-08-21/spain-celebrates-womens-world-cup-at-home-with-carmona-mourning-but-involved |work=San Diego Union-Tribune |accessdate=21 August 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-08-21 |title=La poca vergonya de la premsa de Madrid, això deien del Barça femení a la Champions |url=https://www.elnacional.cat/enblau/ca/televisio/espanya-mundial-premsa-madrid-vergonya-barca-femeni-champions_1080213_102.html |access-date=2023-08-22 |website=En Blau |language=ca}}</ref>

<ref name=":5">{{Cite news |last=Fulton |first=Adam |date=2023-08-21 |title='You all did us proud': what the papers say about England's Women's World Cup loss |language=en-GB |work=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/media/2023/aug/21/you-all-did-us-proud-what-the-papers-say-about-englands-womens-world-cup-loss |access-date=2023-08-22 |issn=0261-3077}}</ref>

sentences.text: The England team stayed overnight in Sydney before returning to London, set to arrive on 22 August; the 2023–24 Women's Super League|Women's Super League would not begin its season until October. Keir Starmer, the UK Leader of the Opposition (United Kingdom)|Leader of the Opposition, called for the team to be recognised with Orders, decorations, and medals of the United Kingdom|Honours for reaching a World Cup final, something which has precedent in men's sport. The match was also featured on the front pages of all British newspapers on 21 August, mostly using images of the team looking disappointed and headlines expressing pride at the achievement of reaching a final.<ref name=":5" />

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |title=Lionesses fly home: England team heading back from Australia after Women's World Cup final defeat to Spain |url=https://news.sky.com/story/lionesses-fly-home-england-side-head-back-from-australia-after-womens-world-cup-final-defeat-to-spain-12944335 |access-date=2023-08-22 |website=Sky News |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text:
{{Main|Rubiales affair}}
During the medal ceremony, RFEF president Luis Rubiales kissed Jennifer Hermoso on the lips. The action drew criticism, particularly towards the continued sexism in the sport, and calls for Rubiales's resignation. In a separate incident at the end of the match, Rubiales was filmed pointing to the Spain players before grabbing his crotch, with the obscene gesture further criticised as he was standing next to the teenage Infanta Sofía of Spain|Infanta Sofía.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |last=Méheut |first=Constant |date=20 August 2023 |title=A Kiss After Spain's World Cup Win Prompts Many to Cry Foul |work=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2023/08/20/world/europe/hermoso-kiss-world-cup-spain-rubiales.html |accessdate=21 August 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-08-21 |title=Spanish FA boss who kissed player filmed making obscene gesture |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/football/luis-rubiales-video-hermoso-kiss-b2396594.html |access-date=2023-08-22 |website=The Independent |language=en}}</ref>

sentences.text: After Hermoso had said she did not expect or like the kiss, Rubiales entered the players' dressing room, reportedly throwing his arm around Hermoso and joking about marrying her in Ibiza. While on a layover returning from Australia, Rubiales published an apology video in which he said that he had no bad intentions and was sorry for distracting from the celebration, saying: "I have to apologise, learn from this, and understand that when you are president you have to be more careful."

references.text: <ref>{{Cite web |last=Filipovic |first=Jill |date=2023-08-22 |title=Opinion: An unwanted kiss on the lips mars Spain's World Cup celebration |url=https://www.cnn.com/2023/08/22/opinions/spanish-football-federation-kiss-womens-world-cup-filipovic/index.html |access-date=2023-08-24 |website=CNN |language=en}}</ref>
<ref>{{Cite news |title=Spanish PM says Rubiales kiss 'unacceptable' |language=en-GB |work=BBC Sport |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/66581263 |access-date=2023-08-24}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |date=2023-08-23 |title=La capitana Ivana Andrés también rechazó salir en el vídeo con Rubiales |url=https://www.relevo.com/futbol/mundial-femenino/ivana-andres-rechazo-salir-video-20230823121905-nt.html |access-date=2023-08-24 |website=Relevo |language=es}}</ref>

sentences.text: Rubiales faced heavy criticism for his actions, and calls for him to resign came from various Spanish footballing bodies as well as the government. He and Vilda tried to make Hermoso support Rubiales, issuing a fake statement when she would not.<ref name="abc" /> Hermoso issued a statement through her union, Futpro, with the union saying the kiss was unacceptable and that they were working on seeing it punished.<ref name=":7" />

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |last1=Snape |first1=Jack |last2=Kassam |first2=Ashifa |date=21 August 2023 |title=Spanish football president's kiss sparks outrage after Women's World Cup final |newspaper=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2023/aug/21/luis-rubiales-kiss-outrage-spanish-football-fa-president-womens-world-cup-final-spain-jenni-hermoso |access-date=21 August 2023}}</ref>
<ref name=":7">{{Cite news |title='Rubiales kiss should not go unpunished' |language=en-GB |work=BBC Sport |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/66598539 |access-date=2023-08-24}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last=Arés |first=Ruby |date=22 August 2023 |title=AFE: "Si Rubiales no dimite, exigimos que se aplique la Ley del Deporte" |language=es |trans-title=ASF: "If Rubiales does not resign, we shall demand that Sports Law be applied" |newspaper=Diario AS |url=https://as.com/futbol/femenino/afe-tajante-si-rubiales-no-dimite-exigimos-que-se-aplique-la-ley-del-deporte-n/ |access-date=22 August 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite web |last=Aguilar |first=Ana |date=23 August 2023 |title=La Liga Femenina pide la inhabilitación de Rubiales ante el Consejo Superior de Deportes |url=https://www.eldiario.es/sociedad/liga-femenina-pide-inhabilitacion-rubiales-consejo-superior-deportes_1_10461522.html |website=eldiario.es}}</ref>

<ref name="abc">{{Cite web |date=22 August 2023 |title=Rubiales rogó a Jenni Hermoso que pidiera disculpas junto a él y la RFEF falseó las declaraciones de la jugadora |url=https://www.abc.es/deportes/futbol/rubiales-rogo-jenni-hermoso-pidiera-disculpas-junto-20230822150910-nt.html |website=ABC (Spain)|ABC}}</ref>

sentences.text: In Spain, the World Cup was broadcast by Televisión Española (TVE), with an average of 5.6 million viewers and a peak of 8.9 million. In addition, public streaming service RTVE Play gathered almost one million viewers, with a total of 2.1 million views.<ref name=":6" /> Post-match celebrations were followed by 6.2 million people, with a peak of 8.7 million.<ref name=":6" />

references.text: <ref name=":6">{{Cite press release |date=21 August 2023 |title=Audiencias: La victoria de España en el Mundial, máximo histórico de todas las competiciones femeninas de fútbol |language=es |trans-title=Ratings: Spain's victory in the World Cup, an all-time high for women's football competitions |url=https://www.rtve.es/rtve/20230821/victoria-espana-mundial-maximo-historico-todas-competiciones-femeninas-futbol/2454292.shtml |access-date=2023-08-21 |publisher=RTVE}}</ref>

sentences.text: In the United Kingdom, the final was watched by a peak audience of 14.8 million and average of 13.3 million on BBC One and ITV1. The BBC reported 12 million peak viewers on BBC One, with an additional 3.9 million views on BBC iPlayer and BBC Sport.

references.text: <ref>{{cite press release |date=21 August 2023 |title=Lionesses' World Cup final defeat sets new record for UK's most-watched women's match |url=https://www.itv.com/news/2023-08-21/lionesses-defeat-sets-new-record-for-uks-most-watched-womens-match |publisher=ITV (TV network)|ITV |accessdate=23 August 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{Cite news |date=21 August 2023 |title=England final draws peak BBC TV audience of 12 million |language=en-GB |work=BBC Sport |url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/66567881 |access-date=21 August 2023}}</ref>

sentences.text: The match was watched by a peak audience of 5.54 million viewers in Australia. It also set a record for the most viewers in the U.S. for a Women's World Cup final not involving the United States women's national soccer team|United States national team, with a peak audience of 2.45 million on Fox Sports|Fox and a combined average of 2.1 million on Fox and Telemundo. The figures were a 88 percent decline from the 2019 final due to the early morning start time and early elimination of the United States.

references.text: <ref>{{cite news |last=Campione |first=Katie |date=21 August 2023 |title=2023 Women's World Cup: Spain's Victory In Final Draws Record Global Audiences |url=https://deadline.com/2023/08/2023-womens-world-cup-final-ratings-spain-england-australia-1235524500/ |work=Deadline (website)|Deadline |accessdate=23 August 2023}}</ref>

<ref>{{cite news |last=Reedy |first=Joe |date=22 August 2023 |title=Women's World Cup final was most watched in US that did not include American team |url=https://apnews.com/article/womens-world-cup-ratings-fox-telemundo-e5a257742e043d8e9877a9d4ddb50bec |publisher=Associated Press |accessdate=23 August 2023}}</ref>
